awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Integrating phylogenetic, genetic, and functional approaches to dissect the role of toxin tolerance in shaping Drosophila biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Unusual adaptations to the environment have long fascinated scientists and the public. There has been much research to understand the evolution of morphological structures (e.g., shape, color, size). However, far less is known about the evolution of novel biochemical adaptations and the impact of these adaptations on the biodiversity of the organisms in which they appear. Of particular interest is how these traits arise if they are costly to the individuals who harbor them. This research investigates the evolution of biochemical adaptations and the genetic and ecological mechanisms that shape them. The research explores the tolerance of insects (fruit flies) to potent toxins in mushrooms that they consume. By investigating the mechanism of toxin tolerance and how this unique adaptation is maintained in this model system, the research will enhance the general understanding of how novel traits emerge and shape biodiversity. This project also includes activities designed to increase public scientific literacy and familiarity with biodiversity by training teachers and students, from middle school to the undergraduate level (particularly from underrepresented minorities), and generating photographic identification guides for insect species associated with mushrooms.

Flies from some groups of Drosophila feed on both toxic and non-toxic mushrooms, and can tolerate high doses of potent cyclopeptide mushroom toxins that are deadly to most other multi-cellular organisms. This research tests hypotheses that predict that: 1) tolerance to these toxic cyclopeptides evolved multiple times; 2) the genetic mechanism of tolerance is not the same in all species; and 3) trade-offs between the physiological costs of tolerance and the benefits of access to a low-competition resource maintain tolerance. The mechanisms of tolerance and their evolution within different fly species are being characterized using metabolomic and transcriptomic analyses that are analyzed in a phylogenetic framework. To assess the genetic basis of variation in toxin tolerance, the researchers are performing artificial selection experiments and genome sequencing. Finally, observational and competition experiments are being used to identify how selective pressures maintain toxin tolerance in natural populations. In sum, this research will provide an in-depth evolutionary, ecological, and physiological assessment of a costly and novel biochemical adaptation, and its impact on biodiversity.

por.por_cntn:
Drosophila, commonly known as fruit flies, are organisms that have intrigued researchers for over a century. Some of the approximately 5000 species of fruit flies evolved the ability to feed on mushrooms that are very poisonous for almost every other animal. Feeding on these poisonous mushrooms not only allows them to have this food source all for themselves; the poison also rids them of their parasites. This intriguing tolerance to high concentrations of mushroom toxins begs the question of how these flies can develop on this unusual resource, what the underlying genetic mechanisms are, and if it requires a lot of energy to maintain this trait.

In our lab, we examined four different mushroom-feeding Drosophila species belonging to separate clades within the immigrans-tripunctata radiation of fruit flies, i.e., they are quite distantly related from each other, which allows for the identification of genetic differences and diverse mechanisms causing the toxin tolerance. These four species were collected in the wild in two distantly located geographic locations: the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, and the Great Smoky Mountains. To explore the mushroom toxin tolerance trait, we subjected the flies to mushroom toxin treatments and evaluated their responses by measuring six fitness traits: 1) developmental time to pupation and eclosion, 2) survival rate to pupation, 3) survival rate to eclosion of the adult flies from their pupae, 4) thorax length as a proxy of overall body size, 5) female fecundity (how many eggs they lay over their lifespan), and adult longevity (how many days the flies live). Using these six traits, the results of our investigations unveiled that Drosophila falleni is the most mushroom toxin-tolerant species in both geographic regions, followed by D. recens, D. neotestacea, and D. tripunctata, in descending order of tolerance. Our results also unveiled both geographical and intraspecific genetic variations in toxin tolerance, adding further complexity to this trait. Thus, there must be both genetic differences between different fruit fly species, in a way that different molecular mechanisms or combinations thereof provide the toxin tolerance trait among species, some species coping better with the toxins than others as a result. Furthermore, within one species from a single location, we observed differences among isolated inbred lines to survive the toxin, which was true for all four species. Our results can be interpreted as a sign of genetic variation that exists in natural populations of these fruit fly species both at the mechanistic level (large scale, between species), as well as at the allelic level (small scale, within each species).

Our research further delved into examining potential fitness costs that may be associated with maintaining the tolerance to mushroom toxins. To understand this aspect, we turned our attention to larval competitive ability—a critical fitness trait for basically all insect species, including Drosophila.  In particular, fruit fly larvae that feed on mushrooms are often unable to move to a different mushroom once the first one is eaten. We studied inbred lines of one species in particular, Drosophila recens, which were compared between both geographical locations. It turned out that the maintenance of the mushroom toxin tolerance does indeed have an impact on larval competitive ability, although only in fruit fly lines from the Great Smokey Mountains location. We observed that lines displaying high toxin tolerance from the Great Smokey Mountains experienced reduced survival rates to eclosion. This result suggests that mushroom toxin tolerance does come with a price, but that geographical factors and the fly’s genetic adaptation to these local factors determine how high that price is.

This research project serves as a critical step toward unraveling the broader ecological and evolutionary implications of the phenomenon of being able to eat deadly poisonous mushrooms. Understanding this phenomenon not only deepens our knowledge of Drosophila biology but also has broader implications for the study of evolutionary ecology, toxicology, and the coevolutionary dynamics between insects and their fungal hosts.
